loans.use: Buy perishable products

loans.name: Rina

texts.en: Rina Z. is currently in the business of selling cooked food in a hotel (restaurant) and is requesting a loan to stock sodas, beer and water to sell. Rina is 40 years old and is married to a policeman. She has three children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a big hotel (restaurant). About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock sodas, beer and water to sell

loans.name: Edelmira

texts.es: Edelmira V. M. de 57 años de edad, reside en Tonacatepeque, ubicado en el departamento de San Salvador. Vive junto a su esposo, un hijo y una nieta, la cual se ha convertido en la mayor inspiración tanto para Edelmira como para su esposo. Ella posee una venta de mariscos, tales como pescado, camarones y otros más, así mismo elabora y vende pupusas en su propia casa, negocio el cual le permite obtener ganancias diarias, las cuales le permiten sostener su hogar junto a su esposo y su hijo. Edelmira es una mujer muy humilde y trabajadora quien desea poder obtener una mejor calidad de vida. Es por esta razón que solicita un préstamo a través del cual pueda comprar mayor cantidad y variedad de mariscos, así mismo comprar maíz, arroz, frijoles y chicharrón para la elaboración de las pupusas, las cuales hace cada noche a las afueras de su casa. Edelmira cuenta con el deseo de mejorar sus ventas y hacer realidad una de sus metas en la vida, la cual es hacer crecer su negocio y beneficiar a su familia.
texts.en:
Edelmira V. M. is 57 years old. She lives in Tonacatepeque, which is in the San Salvador department. She lives with her husband, son, and granddaughter. Her granddaughter has become the greatest inspiration for Edelmira and for her husband. She sells seafood like fish, shrimp, and others. She makes and sells “pupusas” (flatbread stuffed with meat, cheese, or vegetables) in her own house. The business allows her to get daily income. The income allows her to support the household together with her husband and son. Edelmira is a very hard-working and humble woman who wants to be able to have a better quality of life. That is the reason she is requesting a loan. She wants to be able to buy a larger quantity and variety of seafood. She will also buy corn, rice, beans, and “chicharrón” (made from 3 or 4 chunks of pork, served with fried potatoes, sweet or savory corn, onion and spearmint salad) to make the pupusas. She makes them every night outside of her house. Edelmira has the desire to improve her sales and make one of her life goals a reality. That is to make her business grow and benefit her family.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy seafood and ingredients to make pupusas

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria C. is a 50-year-old woman who is married and blessed with two children. She and her family are currently living at Sitio Masikap, Jala-jala, Rizal, Philippines. She is a woman of strong faith to conquer all challenges to achieve her dreams. 

In 2006, Gloria joined ASHI (Ahon sa Hirap Inc.) a micro-finance institution and Kiva partner in the Philippines. As a member of the Institution for almost four years, she has shown an excellent performance in her credit rating (the basis of loans) and therefore she has been trusted by ASHI to obtain several loans.

Gloria has operated a variety store for almost five years but, because of insufficient income from her retailing of small goods and her husband’s earnings, the couple has decided to start a fishing business. She is requesting a new loan of PHP 20,000 to purchase fiberglass, fishing net, materials for the boat, and to pay transportation expenses.

Engaging in this kind of business will help to provide additional proceeds to give the best of life to Gloria’s family and develop their standard of living.

Gloria dreams of growing her variety store into a mini-grocery store and expanding it in their barangay (village).  She also dreams of owning more fish cages to raise more fish to sell. She hopes that both businesses will be the source of stable income to sustain the needs of her family and to send her two children to school until they complete a degree.

Gloria’s greatest dreams are to get out of the spiral of poverty and live happily ever after.

loans.use: To purchase fiberglass, fishing net, materials for the boat, and to pay transportation expenses

loans.name: Mrs. Kunthea Koem Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan, which consists of seventeen people, is located in Srei Snam village in Kandal province. They will each use the loan for a different purpose. Mrs. Kunthea K. is the village bank president who has been selected by the members.

Mrs. Kunthea K. is a seamstress in her village and her husband, Mr. Vanra Cheab, is a farmer who owns 2-hectares (5-acres) of land which he cultivates to support his family.

This family has a problem because their plow is broken but they do not have enough money to fix it. Thus, Mrs. Kunthea K. decided to ask for a loan to repair the plow.

Mrs. Kunthea K. is the mother of two children who are too young to study or work.

loans.use: To repair her plow

loans.name: Tania Marcela

texts.es: Tania Marcela P. M. de 24 años de edad, reside en el Municipio de Soyapango, departamento de San Salvador. Vive junto a su madre, con quien trabaja en conjunto en el negocio. Tania posee una venta de ropa para dama, así mismo comercializa perfumes para hombres y mujeres. Desde hace tres años emprendieron este negocio Tania y su madre, y es así como han ido mejorando su calidad de vida días tras día. Es por esto que Tania solicita un préstamo, a través del cual pueda comprar mayor cantidad de ropa en diferentes tallas, estilos y colores, lo cual le permita contar con mayor clientela, así mismo comprar más perfumes, sobre todo para aprovechar la temporada de febrero en la cual se vende mucho este producto. Tanto Tania como su madre dependen por completo de este negocio por eso es de mucha importancia mejorar las ganancias, ya que son estas las que le permitirán mantener la estabilidad del negocio y así mismo del hogar.
texts.en:
Tania Marcela P. M., age 24, lives in the Soyapango municipality of the San Salvador department. She lives with her mother, and they work together in the business. Tania sells women's clothes. She also sells perfume for men and women. Tania and her mother started this business three years ago. That is how they have been improving the quality of their lives day after day. That is why Tania is asking for a loan to be able to buy a greater quantity of clothing of different sizes, styles, and colors. That will allow her to have more customers. She will also buy more perfume, above all, to take advantage of the February season when she sells a lot of this product. Both Tania and her mother completely depend on this business. That is why it is very important to improve their earnings. The earnings allow them to keep the business and their home stable.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy clothes and perfume

loans.name: Linda

texts.en: Linda E. is currently in the business of selling bread at home and is requesting a loan to purchase more bread to sell. Linda is 41 years old and is married to a journalist. She has five children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a bakery. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase more bread to sell

loans.name: Selenge

texts.en: Ms. O. was born and raised in Ulaanbaatar city. She wants to raise her daughter and son where she grew up but has started to worry about the pollution of the capital city. She noticed that the rivers have dried up and that everything has changed since her childhood. Ms. O. wants to use energy efficient fuel to reduce her own pollution. She is extremely happy with the fuel and believes that she has saved 50% of her fuel costs. About XacBank Eco Products Program: Ulaanbaatar is the coldest capital in the world. Winter temperatures can average -20 Celsius. Sixty percent of the city population live in tents called gers, with wooden frames covered by layers of wool felt. On average, households located in the Ger Districts use 5 tons of coal and 1.5 tons of wood per year. Sixty percent of the pollution in the city during the heating season is attributed to coal burned in the Ger Districts. The bottom fifth spend as much as 40% of their monthly winter income on heating fuels. XacBank has worked with MicroEnergy Credits to launch a line of eco-products consisting of energy efficient stoves and ger blankets, which will reduce energy consumption.

loans.use: To buy clean and energy-efficient heating fuel

loans.name: Yesenia Yaneth

texts.es: Yesenia Yaneth M. R. de 30 años de edad, reside en Ciudad Delgado, ubicado en el departamento de San Salvador. Vive únicamente junto a su esposo, el cual trabaja como comerciante. Yesenia posee una venta de frutas, la cual esta ubicada en el centro de Soyapango, un lugar con alta afluencia de personas y zona de mucho comercio. Así mismo posee una granja en la cual cría y vende pollos. Desde hace 5 años que ella posee este negocio, el cual le ha permitido brindarle la ayuda necesaria a su esposo para los gastos del hogar, así mismo le permite poder contar con una estabilidad económica. Yesenia solicita un préstamo a través del cual pueda comprar mayor cantidad y variedad de fruta, ya que esta se vende mucho en el lugar y así mismo comprar el alimento de los pollos por mayor. Esto lo hace con la ilusión de poder crecer como comerciante y así mismo obtener mayores ganancias.
texts.en:
Yesenia Yaneth M. R. is 30 years old and lives in the city of Delgado, located in the San Salvador department. She lives with her husband, who works as a trader. Yesenia has a business selling fruit which is located in the center of Soyapango, a place with an abundance of people and a busy commercial zone. She also has a farm where she raises and sells chickens. She has had this business for 5 years, and it has allowed her to help her husband with paying the household expenses, and has provided her with greater economic stability. Yesenia requests a loan through which she will be able to buy a greater quantity and variety of fruit, since there is a large market for these products. She will also use the loan to buy feed for her chickens at wholesale. She does this with the hope of being able to grow as a trader, and in this way have better earnings.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy fruit and chicken feed

location.town: Ciudad Delgado en el departamento de San  Salvador

loans.name: Adelaida

texts.en: Adelaida C. is a 53-year-old married woman who lives in Barangay Panaquiao, Isabela, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by buying, raising and selling livestock. Adelaida’s husband Carlos is a laborer and they have ten children who are between 14 and 33 years old. Some of the children have their own families and work, and other children are currently going to school and also help their parents in the business as part of their daily chores. Adelaida joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2003 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD she has been able to increase their family income by engaging in buying, raising and selling livestock. Now she earns an average monthly income of Php 4,000 from her business activities. Adelaida is a member of good standing. Her previous loan of Php 18,000 was used to fund operations of her business activities, and it had a positive impact in both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing Php 18,000 for her 14th loan which she intends to use to buy and fatten livestock to resell at a later date. Adelaida is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which are to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To buy and fatten livestock to sell

loans.name: Wilima

texts.en: Wilima M. is currently in the business of selling sodas and beer at home and is requesting a loan to stock more crates of beer and sodas to sell. Wilima is 30 years old and is married to a policeman. She has six children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more crates of beer and sodas to sell

loans.name: Mrs. Ang Phan Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan, which consists of fifteen people, is located in Srei Snam village in Kandal province. They will each use the loan for a different purpose. Mrs. Ang P. is the village bank president who has been selected by the members.

Mrs. Ang P. is a farmer who owns a small piece of land on which she cultivates rice to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Se Sorn, owns a rice mill and the rest of the time he mills rice to re-sell (milling removes the husk, bran, and germ. This is done largely to prevent spoilage and to extend the storage life of the grain).

Although they try to work hard, this family earns less income than needed. Thus, Mrs. Ang P. decided to ask for a loan to buy more rice for her husband to mill and re-sell.

Mrs. Ang P. is the mother of six children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory, another is a laborer in a mill, another two are enrolled in the local public school, while the others are too young to work or study.

loans.use: To buy more rice to mill and sell

loans.name: Baygalmaa

texts.en: Baygalmaa is a teacher and lives with her 17-year-old daughter. She purchased the eco fuel out of curiosity. So far, she likes the new fuel because it starts burning quickly and preserves heat longer than other fuel. She also plans to sell some of her fuel to her neighbors. She said: “The product was released at the right moment. Ulaanbaatar air pollution is getting worse every year.” About XacBank Eco Products Program: Ulaanbaatar is the coldest capital in the world. Winter temperatures can average -20 Celsius. Sixty percent of the city population live in tents called gers, with wooden frames covered by layers of wool felt. On average, households located in the Ger Districts use 5 tons of coal and 1.5 tons of wood per year. Sixty percent of the pollution in the city during the heating season is attributed to coal burned in the Ger Districts. The bottom fifth spend as much as 40% of their monthly winter income on heating fuels. XacBank has worked with MicroEnergy Credits to launch a line of eco-products consisting of energy efficient stoves and ger blankets, which will reduce energy consumption.

loans.use: To buy clean and energy-efficient heating fuel

loans.name: Imane

texts.en:
Imane is a 27-year-old single woman living with her parents. She has been working as a tailor for the past twelve years. She specializes in tailoring, sewing all type of textiles and wools.

Imane started this business when she was very young and now, after having twelve years of experience, she has became well known by her clients in the whole region.

Today, Imane is requesting $1,000 to buy an embroidery machine and tailoring supplies to offer a variety of products to her clients.

loans.use: To buy an embroidery machine and tailoring supplies

loans.name: Selva

texts.en: Selva P. is currently in the business of selling local alcohol beverages and is requesting a loan to purchase more materials to use to make more alcohol to sell. Selva is 48 years old and is married to a policeman. She has six children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children and to open a bar. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase more materials to use to make more alcohol to sell

loans.name: Janetrix

texts.en:
Janetrix Sella M. is 33 years old and married with seven children. She lives with her family in Bukirimo, Busia district.

Janetrix started her farming business in 1995 to be able to generate income and assist her husband in supporting their large family. In her business she plants tomatoes and vegetables which she later sells in the nearby market.

With her dream of excelling in life, Janetrix also wishes for a better future for her children that will only be guaranteed in education. She would like a loan of Ksh 10,000 to lease another farm and expand her business.

loans.use: To lease an extra farm to expand her business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en: Victoria B. is currently in the business of selling beans, sodas and beer and is requesting a loan to buy more crates of beer and sodas to sell. Victoria is 27 years old and is married to a soldier. She has four children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a wholesale shop. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy more crates of beer and sodas to sell

loans.name: Jonathan

texts.en:
Jonathan W. is a 35-year-old married man with three children living with him in Kwirare in Busia District.

Initially, Jonathan was employed as a sales and marketing agent but left the job as it was not well-paying. In 2002, he ventured into a business making and selling bricks to generate enough income to support his family.

Jonathan would like to acquire a loan of Ksh 30,000 which he will use it to boost his brick-making in terms of labor. It will enable him to be in an economically stable position that will guarantee his children a better education and a brighter future. That is his future goal.

loans.use: To expand his business by boosting his brick making

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Ankbaatar

texts.en:
Ankhbaatar is a driver, a husband and the father of two teenagers (his wife is pictured). He decided to purchase eco fuel because it uses less fuel and stays warmer longer than other fuels. Additionally, he likes the efficiency of the fuel.

As a native citizen of Ulaanbaatar, he wanted to reduce his own contribution to the city’s air pollution. So far, every member of his family has reported staying warmer with the new stove.


About XacBank Eco Products Program:
Ulaanbaatar is the coldest capital in the world. Winter temperatures can average -20 Celsius. Sixty percent of the city population live in tents called gers, with wooden frames covered by layers of wool felt. On average, households located in the Ger Districts use 5 tons of coal and 1.5 tons of wood per year. Sixty percent of the pollution in the city during the heating season is attributed to coal burned in the Ger Districts. The bottom fifth spend as much as 40% of their monthly winter income on heating fuels.

XacBank has worked with MicroEnergy Credits to launch a line of eco-products consisting of energy efficient stoves and ger blankets, which will reduce energy consumption.

loans.use: To buy an energy-efficient heating stove

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en: Erlinda A. is a 58-year-old married woman who lives in Habitat 4, Barangay Bajumpandan, Dumaguete City, Negros Oriental. She earns her living by operating a general store and by buying and selling charcoal and fruit. Erlinda’s husband, Jaime, is 56 years old and drives a motorcycle that earns him Php 4,500 per month.They have three children who are between 22 and 34 years old, two of whom already have families while the other child is currently going to school. Erlinda joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2004 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD she has been able to increase their family income by operating a general store and by buying and selling charcoal and fruit. Now she earns an average monthly income of Php 10,400 from her business activities. Erlinda is a member of good standing. Her previous loan of Php 19,000 was used to fund operations of her general store and her charcoal and fruit business, and it had a positive impact on both the business and on the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing Php 19,000 for her 12th loan which she again intends to use for her businesses. Erlinda is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which are to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To use as additional working capital for her businesses

loans.name: Hicham

texts.en:
Hicham owns a transportation van he uses to deliver passengers from one town to another. He has been involved in this occupation for the past six years but, in 2007, he bought a van and started his own business to earn income. He is the one that supports his wife and two unemployed children with his work.

Today, Hicham is requesting $1,000 to perform maintenance on his vehicle in addition to renovating the van and painting it to offer a good quality of service to his passengers.

loans.use: To perform maintenance on his van and to renovate and paint it

loans.name: Chan Thou's Group

texts.en:
This group loan, which consists of six people, is located in Popeal Khae village in Kandal province. They will each use the loan for a different purpose. Mrs. C. Thou C. is the group leader who has been selected by the members.

Mrs. C. Thou C. is a teacher in the local public school and her husband, Mr. Koeun Korng, is a farmer who owns a small piece of land on which he cultivates rice to support his family living.

In the rice field, this family has some problems because their rice field has infertile soil. Unfortunately, they do not have enough money to change the quality of their land to increase their rice yield this current year. Thus, Mrs. C. Thou C. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer to support their field.

Mrs. C. Thou C. is the mother of four children who are attending the local public school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer for her husband's rice field

loans.name: Kalylova Misirat`s Group

texts.en: Misirat is 55 years old and is married with two sons. Her husband is a pensioner and her elder son is currently a guest worker in Russia, usually sending about 250 dollars monthly. Misirat’s family deals in livestock. They have three milk cows, one horse and a few sheep and also produce milk and milk products such as yogurt, sour cream and kefir (a fermented milk drink). For this loan she is planning to buy a milk cow. In the future she hopes to increase the number of her milk cows and produce enough milk to have supply agreements with kindergartens. Mahpuba, 51, is married and has four children: three daughters and one son. Her elder two daughters are working in Russia as salespersons and her husband works in a tobacco plant as crew chief. She is asking for the loan to buy a milk cow. Janysh is the youngest member of this group. He is just 26 years old and is married with one little daughter. His wife is a member of a farming collective. Janysh lives with his parents, but he hopes in near future to buy proper land and build his own house. At present time he takes an active role in family business: livestock raising and reselling. This loan will let them buy a few lambs. Gulayim, 27, is a married young lady. Her husband currently is an assistant to a driver but, starting in early spring, he usually works as a builder. Gulayim’s family has their own land where they cultivate potatoes. This loan will be used to buy one ton of seed potatoes and fertilizer. ====================================== --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To buy a milk cow

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en:
Ahmad is a 23-year-old single man who lives with his family and two brothers. He started working as a taxi driver in 2005 and services his town and its surroundings. His job has developed over the years and he makes a good income to improve his living situation.

Ahmad took a loan before and now he's asking today for his second loan of $1,000 to take his car to the garage to be repaired and have maintenance performed on it after being in bad circumstances lately.

loans.use: To perform repairs and maintenance on his taxi

loans.name: Racheal Waturi

texts.en:
Racheal is 35 years old and is married with three children. Her husband, Stephen, is a businessman and they live in Ruaka, an upcoming center in the outskirts of Nairobi. Racheal has put up her tailoring shop in Ruaka trading center.

Racheal was introduced to KADET by her friends with whom she formed a group. They joined KADET so that they could access loans for their businesses. Racheal has never borrowed from other sources and this is her first loan with KADET. The loan she has applied for she will use to buy more materials for her tailoring business.

Racheal hopes to grow her business so that she can become a supplier of materials on a wholesale basis.

loans.use: To buy more tailoring materials

loans.name: Margret

texts.en:
Margret P. is currently in the business of selling beans and charcoal at the market and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell.  Margret is 38 years old and married; her husband is a driver. She has 6 children, all of whom go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a charcoal store.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: stock more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Eric Ouma

texts.en:
Erick Ouma O. is 22 years old and married to Maurine Auma; they live in Nyalenda in the city of Kisumu. They just wedded recently and so they have no children at the moment.  

Erick sells oil which is mostly used in lubricating cars. He is looking for a lender through Kadet Ltd/Kiva to enable him to get funds to purchase five gallons of oil. He has orders to transport some of the oil to to some of his customers in Nairobi. He hopes to be the leading supplier of used oil in Kisumu and wants to use the loan to expand his business. 

Erick's wife is a tailor and he intends to use the profits to buy her another sewing machine to enable her to run her business well and help boost the family income.

loans.use: Purchase 5 gallons of oil to add to his stock

loans.name: Guo

texts.en:
Guo C. is currently in the business of selling sodas and beans at home and is requesting a loan to buy more bags of beans to sell.  Guo is 20 years old and married to a doctor. She has 1 child, who attends school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a depot for selling sodas.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: buy more bags of beans to sell

loans.name: Mrs. Sam Ann Yem Village Bank Group

texts.en:
A village bank loan, which consists of twenty-six people, is located in Srei Snam village in Kandal province. All the the members of the group are shown above, but some of them are blocked.

Mrs. Sam Ann Y. is the village bank president selected by the members, who all use the loan for different purposes. She is a grocer in the local village and her husband, Mr. Vey Phan, is a farmer who owns a small piece of land where he cultivates rice to support his family. In order to improve their living conditions, Mrs. Sam Ann Y. decided to ask for a loan to start a new business buying more rice to resell because it can generate a high income. Mrs. Sam Ann Y. is the mother of four children, two of whom work in a massage shop, while the other two are enrolled in the local public school.

loans.use: To buy more rice to resell

loans.name: Easther

texts.en:
Easther K. is currently in the business of selling sugar and onions in the market and is requesting a loan to buy more bags of sugar to sell.  Easther is 23 years old and married; her husband is a carpenter. She has 2 children, who attend school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to educate her children.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: buy more bags of sugar to sell

loans.name: Hellen

texts.en: Hellen M. M. is forty-seven years old, married, and has three children aged between twenty-four and twelve years old. Her business is located at Ndunyu Sabuk market in Thika, Kenya. She has been supplying cereals to the local people. She has been in this business for the last four years and she says that her major challenge is that there are many people doing the same business as hers. However, she is determined to work hard and become the market leader. She is using her loan to buy more cereals to expand her business. In future, she sees herself having a big business. She is very innovative and hard-working.

loans.use: beans and maize

loans.name: Anna Amagoye

texts.en:
Anna Amagoye E. is a tailor in Migori. She is married to Jotham Kidima who is a teacher and they have five children.

Anna has been in the tailoring business for the past 13 years and has thus created a big clientele due to the fact that she normally looks out for the latest designs and tries them out. The niche she has created makes it possible to beat out her competitors.

Anna is looking for a lender through Kadet Ltd to enable her to buy more fabric to add to her stock and to buy another sewing machine. She is a well-known tailor in the village as she gets orders for school uniforms from the local schools in her area. There is also a high demand for more different fabrics/materials right now. She has a good credit history with Kadet Ltd as she has repaid her previous loans well.

She hopes to use the money to buy school uniform materials since they are in high demand as schools open this month.

loans.use: Buy materials/fabric to add to her stock

loans.name: Cilla

texts.en:
Cilla C. is currently in the business of selling local alcohol and beer out of her home and is requesting a loan to purchase more materials to use. Cilla is 20 years old and is married to a husband who is a security guard. She has 2 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a bar and restaurant.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations.

BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase more materials to use

loans.name: Amanbaeva Jambu's Group

texts.ru:
Аманбаевой Жамбу 42 года, она разведенная мать 2 детей:старшему сыну 13 лет и учится в 7 классе, а дочь дошкольного возраста. Заемщица производит и реализует кисломолочные продукты, пирожки и беляши на скотном рынке Узгена. В неделю она выходит на работу два дня. Этим делом она начала заниматься два года назад, с момента развода, начальный капитал был получен в долг у сестры, который был равен около 70 долларам. Данный кредит будет использован для закупа 1 мешка муки, 1 мешка картошки, 5 кг курута (молочный продукт) - это около 1000 сом. Оставшаяся часть будет использована для аренды земли для выращивания риса. В будущем клиент планирует расширить ассортимент производимых блюд, и готовить плов, шурпа, манты и салаты. 

Манзурахон 24 года, она замужем и воспитывает двоих детей. Ее супруг работает таксистом в Узгене. Сама заемщица занимается выпечкой и реализацией лепешки уже два года. продукцию реализует на центральном рынке Узгена. На полученный кредит она планирует закупить 13 мешков муки, 14 кг сухого молока, соль и дрожжи. 

Маматкамил женат, и воспитывает 3 детей. Около их дома у них есть собственный ларек по продаже продуктов питания, на точке работает его супруга. Сам Маматкамил таксует в Узгене. Кредит будет использован для аренды 1 га земли для выращивания риса. В данное время он копит деньги, чтобы купить хорошую машину, чтобы у него была возможность работать на более рентабелных маршрутах, например Узген - Бишкек (столица).

Бурулкан, 52 года, замужем и мать 1 сына. Сыну 15 лет, ош школьник. Ее супруг работает частным строителем. Сама Бурулкан производит кисломолочные продукты, т.к. курут, айран, кефир, сметана. Кредит будет получен для закупа доеной коровы. Это позволит ей получать больше молока и увеличить объем производства молочных изделий.

*** STORY GOES HERE ***

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.
texts.en:
Jambu A. is 42 years old. She is a divorced mother of two children. Her oldest son is 13 years old and is in 7th grade, and the daughter is of preschool age. Jambu manufactures and sells dairy products, piroshky and belyashi (meat pies) at a livestock market in Uzgen. She goes to work twice per week. She started this business two years ago, since her divorce. Jambu obtained the starting capital of approximately 70 dollars from her sister as a loan. The current loan will be used for the purchase of 1 bag of flour, 1 bag of potatoes and 5 kg of kurut (milk curd product) – this is about 1000 som. The remaining sum will be used to lease land for growing rice. In the future, Jambu plans to expand the selection of prepared dishes and cook pilaf, shurpa (spiced lamb soup), manty (dumplings) and salads. Manzurahon is 24 years old. She is married and is raising two children. Her husband works as a taxi driver in Uzgen. Manzurahon has been involved in baking and selling flatbread for two years. She sells her product at the Uzgen central market. She plans to use this loan to purchase 13 bags of flour, 14 kg of dried milk, salt and yeast. Mamatkamil is married and raising 3 children. They own a small food store near their home, where his wife works. Mamatkamil works as a taxi driver in Uzgen. He will use this loan to lease 1 hectare of land for growing rice. Currently, he is saving money to buy a good car to enable him to work more profitable transportation routes, for example Uzgen – Bishkek (the capital). Burulkan is 52 years old, married and is a mother of 1 son. Her son is 15 years old, and he is a student. Her husband works as a private building contractor. Burulkan manufactures dairy products, such as kurut, ayran (yogurt beverage), kefir and sour cream. This loan will be used for the purchase of a dairy cow. This will allow Burulkan to obtain more milk and increase the capacity of dairy product manufacturing.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of flour, potatoes, kurut and lease of land

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samuel is 46 years old, married to Grace Nyira, and they have two school-going children. He has been in the auto repair business since 2000, operating in Naivasha town. In his outdoor garage, he repairs vehicles which have a problem.

He was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his first loan with which he plans to buy a fully equipped toolbox.

His future plan is to build his own indoor garage to operate from instead of working from the roadside.

loans.use: To buy a new tool box for his mechanics work

loans.name: Martin

texts.en:
Martin is a 24-year-old gentleman who operates a grocery shop in Naivasha town. He sells onions only, and this he has done for the past three years

He was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his first loan. He plans to buy more onions to sell as he has already received large delivery orders.

His future hope is to get more and bigger distributorship deals for onions in Naivasha.

loans.use: To buy morre onions for sale

loans.name: Paul

texts.en:
Paul is 35 years old, married to Hellen Akinyi, and they have two school-going children. He has been in the auto repair business since 2001, operating in Naivasha town.

He was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his first loan. He plans to use the cash to start a battery-charging business on the side, thus increasing his income. So he will buy a battery charger. With the profits from the loan he hopes to open more battery-charging shops as this is a profitable business and not many people have ventured into it.

Naivasha is an urban/rural town so many people use batteries as a source of energy in their homes and businesses.

loans.use: To start a battery-charging business on the side

loans.name: Judy

texts.en:
Judy is 39 years old, married to Andrew Karanja, and they have two school-going children. She has been in this quarry business since 2007.

She was introduced to KADET by her friend, and this will be her second loan. She plans to use the cash to buy another piece of land where she will extract more stones for sale. This will increase her income.

In the near future, she plans to buy a lorry which she will use to transport the stones to sell in other markets.

loans.use: To buy another piece of land for her quarry business

loans.name: Toyin

texts.en:
Toyin is 50 years old and married with 5 children. She loves her children so much that she works at sales for long hours to meet their basic needs. She sells drinks and pepper soup in her restaurant. Her customers patronize her pub more in the evenings when they have left work.

Toyin loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She hopes to sell her drinks at wholesale prices in the future. She hopes for the loan amount of NGN 80,000 to purchase more drinks and soup ingredients to make more pepper soup to sell. She is grateful in anticipation to Kiva lenders and promises to use her money positively.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and soup ingredients

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samuel is 28 years old, married to Agnes Njoki, and they have a two-month-old baby. Samuel has been operating a motorcycle transport business for the last three years within Naivasha town.

He was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his first loan. He will use the cash to buy a new helmet and tires for his motorcycle.

He plans to buy a car which he will use as a taxi. This will increase his future income.

loans.use: Buy new tires and a new helmet

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en:
Stephen is 28 years old, married to Edith Auma, and they have a one-year-old child. He has been in the vehicle repair business since 2001.

He was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his first loan. He plans to use the cash to buy fiberglass and special glue for vehicle repair.

His future dream is to open a new, bigger workshop so that he can serve more clients.

loans.use: To buy fiberglass and glue for use in his business

loans.name: Rashidat

texts.en:
Rashidat is 50 years old and married with 4 children. Her children are excelling in their school work and jobs. She is a hard-working woman. She is also a friendly woman.

Rashidat uses her friendly skills to attract more customers to her business. To earn a living, she sells washing and bathing soap at retail prices to her customers. She hopes for the loan amount of NGN 70,000 to purchase more washing and bathing soaps to sell. She hopes to expand her business in the future. She is thankful in anticipation for your kind support.

loans.use: To purchase more washing and bathing soap to sell

loans.name: John Lawrence

texts.en:
John Lawrence G. is from the village of Brgy. Maddiangat, Quezon, Nueva Vizcaya. He is 29 years old. John Lawrence is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, John Lawrence owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for fattening and for sale. John Lawrence has been engaged in his business for over 2 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, John Lawrence joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. John Lawrence is requesting a loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This will be the first loan taken out by John Lawrence from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en: Mercy is 59 years old, married with 5 children, and lives in Lagos State, Nigeria.  She was once into the sale of clothes and gift items and later changed her line of business to the sale of household items like cooking pots, plates, spoons, cups and more. This has been very profitable and she hopes to improve and expand her business in future. She hopes for a loan of NGN 140,000 to purchase more cooking pots, plates, spoons, and cups to sell. She thanks all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more cooking pots, plates, spoons, and cups to sell

loans.name: Aleksan

texts.en:
Aleksan A. was born in 1949 in Ijevan. He has 3 children: two daughters and a son. All Aleksan’s children are married: his daughters live separately from their parents and his son’s family lives with Aleksan and his wife.

For about 15 years, Aleksan Antnonyan worked as a driver; now he and his wife are engaged in farming. With the profits from farming, Aleksan provides his family’s needs, such as buying necessary furniture and organizing his children’s weddings. He also helped his son to set up his own business. His son’s business consists of selling spare parts and petrol. Aleksan helps his son in business, and now they are constructing their own shop. Aleksan needs 600.000 AMD as a loan to complete the shop’s construction.

loans.use: To complete their shop’s construction

loans.name: Sarab Ali Group

texts.en:
This is the Sarab Ali group; Qader Ali is the leader of this 4-member group. He is 38 years old, married and the father of 6 children. Qader Ali has a weaving business, and he has been involved in this business for more than five years. He has lots of experience in weaving. With this loan he wants to buy some necessary tools.

The second member of the Sarab Ali group is Razia who wants to take out a loan for her husband. He has a metal-working shop. With this loan he wants to buy more iron to make doors and chairs. The third member is Faizullah who wants to take a loan for his fresh fruit cart; with this loan he wants to complete his stock. The last member of the Sarab Ali group is Zia Gull who makes and sews quilts. With this loan she wants to buy more white cloth and some other necessary things. They all thank Kiva lenders and AFS in Afghanistan.

loans.use: buy necessary implements for weaving

loans.name: Mrs. Mi Moung Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank loan which consists of eight people is located in Srey Snom village in Kandal province. Mrs. Mi M. is the village bank president who has been selected by the members; all use the loan for different purposes. She is 55 years old and a chicken seller in the local market. She is a widow who has no children and she lives with four siblings, two of whom help with her business. In order to improve their living conditions, Mrs. Mi M. decided to ask for a loan to buy more chickens to re-sell to expand her business and increase the income from it.

loans.use: To buy more chickens to re-sell

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en:
Gladys is a 42 years old; she is a divorcee with 2 children and resides in Lagos state, Nigeria. Life has not been easy for her, caring for her children alone. Her youngest child is 15 and is doing well in school. She sells drinks and pepper soup to her customers. She hopes for a standard restaurant in future. She hopes for loan amount of NGN 140,000 to purchase more drinks to sell.

She thanks all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell

loans.name: Mulikat

texts.en: Mulikat sells natural medicines to make a living in her community. Natural medicines are essential in Nigeria and the demand for them is high. She makes the natural medicines by herself, using herbs and roots. She hopes to own a natural medicine clinic in the future. She hopes for the loan amount of NGN 50,000 to purchase more herbs to make more natural medicines to sell. She has been in this business for a considerable number of years. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more herbs to make more natural medicines to sell

loans.name: Ini

texts.en: Ini is a businesswoman; she sells drinks. She sells at retail prices to her customers. She is hard-working and hopes for another line of business in future which is the sale of kerosene. She hopes for a loan of NGN 140,000 to purchase more drinks to sell and invest in the kerosene business. Ini is married; blessed with 2 daughters who are doing well. They live in Lagos state, Nigeria. She appreciates Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell

loans.name: Tabaldyeva Baktygul`s Group

texts.en:
Baktygul is leader of this group. She is 44 years old, married with 5 children. Her husband works as a builder in town. She has a livestock breeding business. Usually she fattens cows, bulls, and some sheep. She looks after them for about 3 months then sells them at the local market. Almost every Sunday, her husband goes to market and examine the livestock for sale. If he finds a suitable one, often he buys it. This loan will be used to buy a cow for breeding. Their monthly income is about USD 50.

Irsalathan, 38, is a married woman with 4 children: two daughters and 2 sons. At the present time, her husband is in Russia. He works there in a construction company as a builder. She hopes to buy 4 sheep with this loan. She has a little farm where she will look after them and when spring comes, the sheep will be sent to highland pasture.

Uulkan is 20 years old and a married woman. She has a 1-year-old son. Her husband is working in Moscow. Every month he sends home about 100 USD. Uulkan works in the animal sales business. Every week she goes to the local animal market. She sells about 2 cows per week. Her monthly income is about 150 USD. This loan will be used to buy a bull.

Kanymbu is 40 years old, married, and has 3 children. The elder son is in Russia; other two are still pupils. Her husband is a physics teacher and earns about 80 USD per month. Kanymbu sells different types of groats like buckwheat, millet and oatmeal and other food and necessary items in her own kiosk. This loan will be used to buy 50 kg of sugar, 50 kg of rice, 100 kg of pasta, soaps, detergent and cigarettes for her kiosk.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious, socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To buy a cow

loans.name: Ikoagba

texts.en:
Ikogba sells garri to make a living in Lagos State, Nigeria. Garri is mA. from cassava, and it is the most common foodstuff in Nigeria. She has been in this business for over 13 years and has had success. She hopes for a big business in the future. She hopes for NGN 100,000 to purchase more bags of garri to sell.

Ikogba is married and has 4 children. Her eldest child is 20 years old. She hopes to support her husband in sponsoring their children for higher education. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of garri to sell

loans.name: Mr. Mrs. Veuk Va Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mr. Veuk V. is a village bank president who has been elected by the members of the bank. The members use their loans for different purposes. The village bank, which consists of thirteen people, is located in Kbal Chrouy village in Kandal province.

Mr. Veuk V. is a fisherman, and his wife, Mrs. Srin Yen, is a fish seller who sells the fish that her husband catches. This family has a problem because their fishnets are too old to use, but they do not have enough money to buy new ones. Thus, Mr. Veuk V. decided to ask for a loan to buy a new fishnet to replace the old one.

He is a father of three children who are attending a local public school.

loans.use: To buy a new fishnet

loans.name: Funke

texts.en:
Funke is 36 years old. She is married and has 3 children. Her eldest child is 9 years old, and she is happy because her children are doing well in school.

She is a hair dresser who makes lovely Nigerian and western hairstyles for her customers. Her customers are mostly residents and friends. She hopes to own a world class beauty salon in the future.

She hopes for a loan of NGN 70,000 to purchase more hair extensions, one generator, and one deep freezer. She has a good relationship with LAPO. LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organisation) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more hair extensions, one generator, and one deep freezer

loans.name: Nneka

texts.en:
Nneka is 32 years old. She is married and has 5 children. They are doing well in their various schools. She and her husband hope to educate their children at the university level.

She sells frozen food and foodstuffs like rice, tomato paste, oil, etc., to make a living in Lagos State, Nigeria. She finds this business interesting due to the interaction with her customers. She has been in the business for some years and hopes to expand her business in the future.

She hopes for a loan of NGN 50,000 to purchase more foodstuffs and frozen food to sell. She says thanks to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs and frozen food to sell

loans.name: Nhor

texts.en:
Mrs. Nhor M. is 49 years old, and she lives in Dei Chrab village in Takeo province. She is a mother of two children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory. Her husband is on the right of the photo.

She and her husband, Mr. Chhoem Ben, are farmers who own a small piece of land to cultivate rice to support their family. They have a problem in the rice field because it is far from the irrigation system. They do not have the needed water supply to support their farm. Thus, Mrs. Nhor M. decided to ask for loan to buy a water machine, and with the rest of the loan, she would like to buy more fertilizers.

loans.use: To buy a water machine and more fertilizers

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter is 32 years old and married to Lucy Wangui. They have three children, two of whom are in school and the other is three months old.  Peter owns a motorcycle which he uses to transport people and goods to different places.  This has been his source of income for the last five years within the town of Naivasha.

Peter was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his first loan.  He plans to use it to buy a new motorcycle and employ a transport operator, hence increasing his income.

Peter plans to buy a minibus in future to transport people from one place to another.

loans.use: To buy a new motorcyle

loans.name: Ajoke

texts.en: Ajoke is 47 years old. She is married with 4 children and resides in Lagos state, Nigeria.  Ajoke is a merchant who sells kerosene at retail prices to her customers. She has been in this business for 10 years and is doing well. She supports her husband, a fashion designer, in providing for her children’s education and other basic family needs. She hopes to expand her business in the future. She is requesting a loan in the amount of NGN 140,000 to purchase more kerosene to sell. She says thanks to lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more kerosene to sell

loans.name: Chork

texts.en: Mr. Chork P. is 46 years old and he lives in Srae Vong village, Takeo province. He and his wife, Mrs. Choun Mich (on the right of the photo), are farmers who own a 1.5-hectare field where they cultivate rice. Mr. Chork P. needs 1,300,000 Riel from AMK/Kiva to buy fertilizer and pesticides for his field crop and a cow for breeding.  Mr. Chork P. has six children: one is employed in a garment factory, one is a construction worker, three are students in the local school and one is too young to study or work.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pesticides for his field crop and a cow for breeding

loans.name: Mrs. E De Village Bank Group

texts.en:
The village bank loan, which consists of fifteen peopL., is located in Kbal Chrouy village in Kandal province. Mrs. E D. is the village bank president selected by the members who all use the loan for different purposes. She is 57 years old and the mother of three children who are enrolled in the local public school.

Mrs. E D. sells the fish that her fisherman husband, Mr. Hok Choeung, catches. This family has a problem because their fish nets are too old to use, but they D. not have enough money to buy new ones. Thus, Mrs. E D. decided to apply for a loan to buy fish nets.

loans.use: To buy fish nets

loans.name: Marissa's Group

texts.en:
Marissa V. is from the village of Tueg Bitag Grande, Baggao, Cagayan. She is 30 years old. Marissa is the group leader of a 7-member group loan offered by ASKI/Kiva. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Marissa is married and has 3 young children. Marissa owns and operates a business raising livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for fattening and for resale. Marissa has been involved in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2007, Marissa joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marissa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from ASKI. Marissa is requesting a new loan, her second, which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to save as a reserve for future emergencies. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future

loans.name: Freria

texts.en:
Freria N. Simiyu is a 50-year-old widow living in Kwirare in Busia District with her five (5) children. Being a sole bread winner for her family, Freria abandoned farming, venturing into fish sales in 1990, which, according to her, generates more income than farming.

Just like any other business person, Freria would like to see her business expand so as to ensure economic stability for her family. This, and the knowledge she got from KMET on economic development, made her think of the possibility of financial assistance in the form of a loan. She would like to acquire a KES 20,000 loan that would be used to increase her stock so that she will earn more revenue.

loans.use: To increase her stock.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter is 35 years old and married. He has one child, age 6, who currently attends school. He is a farmer in the South Rift Valley, near Litein, Kenya, and has two employees currently working for him. He's been farming for over nine years and sells milk, eggs, pineapples, maize, and tea. In addition to his farm, Peter also owns and helps run a medical clinic. He says that the main challenges to his farming business are the expensive farm inputs and feeds, and that markets are sometimes not available for his produce.

Peter requested this loan through Juhudi Kilimo for KES 65,000 to purchase a dairy cow. He says that the extra income from this loan will increase the family's income and make it easier to pay school fees for his child. In the future, he would like to improve on his dairy breeds for better milk production, and he also hopes that market conditions will stabilize in his area.

Peter is grateful Juhudi Kilimo is focusing on the rural poor who would otherwise have limited or no access to capital. He likes the funding for dairy cows as it is not just for financial purposes but also for social purposes, as it improves the health of families.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow.

loans.name: Assiongbonvi

texts.en: Assiongbonvi A. owns a books store where he sells a variety of books in Elmina.  Assiongbonvi has received senior high education. He is married and has four children. His wife is a hair dresser. Assiongbonvi has been selling books for some time now. He is responsible for paying school fees, bills and other family expenses. His loan will be used to buy Christian books in addition to the textbooks, novels, and literature books for sale. He hopes to use the new profits from his business to save to reinvest into his business to increase his capital.

loans.use: To buy Christian books in addition to textbooks, novels and literature books for sale.

loans.name: Mrs. Sarom Long Village Bank Group

texts.en: A village bank loan which consists of twelve people is located in Kbal Chrouy village in Kandal province. Mrs. Sarom L. is a village bank president who has been selected by the members who will all use the loan for different purposes. She is a vegetable seller in the local village and her husband, Mr. TO. Sorn, is an ice crE. seller who can earns little income to support his family. In order to improve their living conditions, Mrs. Sarom L. decided to ask for a loan to buy more vegetables to sell. She is a mother of five children who are enrolled in the local public school.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables to sell.

loans.name: Ekua Maame

texts.en: Ekua Maame B. is single and has two children. She has received junior high education. Ekua Maame sells smoked fish at Elmina, which she has been doing for some time now. Ekua Maame uses her income to pay school fees, utility bills and other family expenses.  Ekua Maame will use the loan to purchase more fresh fish to process (smoke) for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Ekua Maame plans to save to reinvest into business.

loans.use: To purchase more fresh fish to process (smoke) for sale.

loans.name: Mich

texts.en: Mrs. Mich L. is 52 years old and lives in Spueu village, Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Phorn Phann, are farmers who own a 1.5-hectare field to grow plants and rice. In order to support their crop, Mrs. Mich L. is applying for a loan of 1,300,000 Riel from AMK to buy fertilizer. Mr. Phorn Phann is also a construction worker who earns a small salary to support the family. Mrs. Mich L. is the mother of five children. Two of her children work in the garment factory, one is a farmer who helps with the farming business, and the other two are students in the local public school. Her husband is on the right in the photo.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer to support her crops.

loans.name: Titilayo

texts.en: Titilayo is a hard-working woman and she is very determined to excel in her business and family life. She sells sarongs, clothes, shoes and bags at retail prices to her customers. She hopes to own a boutique in the future. She hopes for a loan amount of NGN 80,000 to purchase more sarongs and shoes to sell. She has a good relationship with LAPO. She is married with 5 children. Her husband is mechanic and he also supports the household. She is indeed grateful to all KIVA lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs and shoes to sell.

loans.name: Helena

texts.en: Helena M. is married and has six dependants. She has received senior high education. Helena sells cloth and bags of water in Elmina, which she has been doing for some time now. Her husband is a welder. Helena uses her income to support her husband in the payment of school fees, utility bills, and family expenses. Helena will use the loan to purchase more materials cloths and bags of water to sell. With the new profits from her expanded business, Helena plans to save to further educate her children.

loans.use: To purchase more materials, cloths and bags of water to sell.

loans.name: Ny

texts.en: Mrs. Ny P. is 47 years old and she lives in Chheu Teal Phluoh village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate rice. Her husband, Mr. Trach P. wants to start a new business as a horse driver who resells coconuts door-to-door. In order to support her husband's business, Mrs. Ny P. decided to ask for a loan to buy a horse and a cart for this business. With this loan, she hopes to increase income and improve her family living. Mrs. Ny P. is a mother of five children, one of whom supports the father's business and another who is construction worker; two others are students in the local school, while the youngest one is 3 years old.

loans.use: To buy a horse and cart for the business.

loans.name: Ajoke

texts.en: Ajoke is gifted in business. She has poultry and a fishpond. She is so happy that her business is expanding. She needs more expansion and she knows that KIVA lenders can help. She hopes for a loan of NGN 100,000 to purchase more poultry and fingerlings to raise and sell. She is married to a businessman and they have four children. She is 42 years old. She is happy because her children and business are excelling. She is looking forward to making use of this loan effectively. She has a good relationship with Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO).  LAPO is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa. She says thanks to all KIVA lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more poultry and fingerlings.

loans.name: Hamida

texts.en: Hamida is a married woman of 22 years old. She got married early and she has 2 young children. Because their living situation is hard with a lot of expenses such as family expenses, schooling expenses, hospitality, etc., Hamida decided to help her husband with the household finances, so she started selling clothes from her home in 2008. And she has been able to have a good number of clients passing by her home to buy clothes. Today, Hamida is requesting to borrow US$ 800 to buy a big quantity of clothes at lower prices to make a good profit.

loans.use: buy a big quantity of clothes at lower prices

loans.name: Sopheap

texts.en: Mrs. Sopheap C. is 49 years old and she lives in Chheu Teal Phluoh village, Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a 2-hectare field to cultivate rice on. Her husband, Mr. Ton Tim, is a cow middleman which has allowed them to support their family's living.  In order to support her farming and her husband's business, Mrs. Sopheap C. is now requesting loan of 2,000,000 Riel to buy fertilizer and pesticide to grow more crops; she would use any remainder of the loan to enlarge her husband's business. This couple has three children, two of whom are students in the local school; the other one is a farmer.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, pesticide to grow more crops, and enlarge her husband's business.

loans.name: Celestina

texts.en: Celestina T. is single. She has received junior high education.  Celestina sells fabrics, lining, and other sewing materials at Elmina, which she has been doing for some time now. Celestina uses her income to pay rent and utility bills.  Celestina will use the loan to buy more sewing materials like fabric, lining, etc. for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Celestina plans to save to reinvest into the business.

loans.use: Celestina will use the loan to buy more sewing materials like fabric, lining, etc. for sale.

loans.name: Eab

texts.en:
Mrs. Eab K. is 47 years old and she lives in Chheu Teal Phluoh village, Takeo province. She is married with three children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory while the last one is a student in the public school.

Mrs. Eab K. and her husband are farmers who own a 3-hectare field to cultivate rice on. They lack financial resources to support dry-season cultivation of rice. So now, Mrs. Eab K. is requesting 2,000,000 Riel from AMK to buy fertilizer, pesticide, and gasoline to support their crops. With the help of her loans from AMK, she has been able to increase the family income from her farming work.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, pesticide and gasoline for their crops

loans.name: Mena Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the Mena Group. They are small-scale businesswomen based in Makeni city, in northern Sierra Leone. They are seeking a loan of SLL 800,000 each to enable them to further expand their businesses. Consequently, they will make more profit and improve their standard of living.

The leader of this group is Fatmata K.. Fatmata is age 42 and was born in Makeni. She is married with 6 children. Her husband is a businessman and 3 of her children are adults; 2 are attending secondary school and 1 is in primary school. For 22 years now, Fatmata has been selling market food – rice, palm oil (the most popular cooking oil), Maggi (used to give sauce a sweet taste), onions, fish, vegetable oil, sugar, etc. With this loan, she will expand her business by buying rice, palm oil, Maggi cubes, onions, fish, vegetable oil, sugar, etc. wholesale to add to her current stock.

loans.use: Buy rice, palm oil, Maggi cubes, onions, fish, vegetable oil, sugar, etc. wholesale

loans.name: Chioma

texts.en: Chioma sells frozen foods, other foodstuffs, and cosmetics at retail prices to her customers. She sells for long hours to enable her to meet the basic needs of her family. With these varied items, she hopes to make her business sustainable. She hopes for the loan amount of NGN 90,000 to purchase more frozen foods and other foodstuffs to sell. She hopes to grow her business in the future. She is 33 years old, married to a commercial driver, and they have 4 children. Her youngest child is 3 years old. Her children are still dependent on her and they attend school. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs and frozen foods to sell

loans.name: Heba

texts.en: Heba is a 25-year-old married woman and mother of one child. Graduating from university with a major in photography, she opened a photography shop in her town in 2008, after seeing a need for such services in the region. She photographs speciA. events like weddings and she's happy with her work. Today, Heba is requesting to borrow US$ 700 in order to purchase an additionA. camera because she's planning to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: purchase an additional camera

loans.name: Georgina

texts.en:
Georgina M. is married and has six dependents. She has received senior high education. Georgina sells frozen fish at Elmina, which she has been doing for some time now. Her husband is a tailor. Georgina uses her income to help her husband in the payment of school fees and the other family expenses. Georgina will use the loan to purchase more fresh fish to freeze and then resell. With the new profits from her expanded business, Georgina plans to save to help her husband build a house for the family.

This picture was taken at the market. She is the one in the white top and with her bag hanging at her side. The people you see around her fish are customers waiting to buy some of her fish.

loans.use: to purchase more  fresh fish to freeze and then resell

loans.name: Chinwe

texts.en: Chinwe sells electronics to make a living. She loves this business, because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She is happy with her business and family life. She hopes for the loan amount of NGN 100,000 to purchase more electronics to sell. She hopes to own an electronics company in the future. She is married with 3 children and her children are doing well in their school work. Her husband is businessman and he also supports the household. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more eletronics to sell

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en: Comfort A. sells frozen fish at Elmina.  Comfort has received no formal education.  She is married and has four children. Her husband is a plumber. Comfort has been selling frozen fish for some time now. She helps her husband in the payment of school fees and some other family expenses. Her loan will be used to buy more fish to be frozen for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save to help her husband with the building of their family house.

loans.use: to buy more fresh fish to be frozen for sale

loans.name: Naji

texts.en:
Naji is a 30-year-old married man with one child. In 2008, he opened a small restaurant in his town as his own business because this market is well known in the whole region. He offers snacks, soft drinks and narjile, a special Lebanese tobacco, in his restaurant. All the clients visit him to have a good time and a comfortable seat with the narjile, the traditional tobacco. 

Today, Naji is requesting to borrow $1,200 to purchase more food equipment and supplies to perform renovations to his shop and enlarge his operation.

loans.use: Food accessories and supplies

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary P. sells frozen fish in Elmina. Mary has received a senior high education. She is married and has two children. Her husband is a fisherman. Mary has been selling frozen fish for some time now. She is responsible for supporting her husband in the payment of school fees, bills and other family expenses.

Her loan will be used to buy more fresh fish to be frozen by way of preserving it for resale at a later period. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save and to improve her capital to enable her to increase her stock.

loans.use: Her loan will be used to buy more fresh fish to be frozen for resale

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en:
Mohamad is a 52-year-old married man with two children. He has owned a clothing shop for the past 20 years. He’s well known in the whole region because his shop has been there a long time. With his business income, he's able to raise his children. 

Today, Mohamad is requesting to borrow $1,000 to buy new clothes and fill his shop with new collections to meet the demands of his clients.

loans.use: Buy new clothes and fill his shop with new collections
