loans.name: Ta-Taesu-Tekeh Group

texts.en:
These are the members of the Ta-Taesu-Tekeh group. They are small-scale businesswomen in the northern city of Makeni. This will be their first loan from SMT/Kiva. With the help of this loan, these entrepreneurs will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and better profits. Consequently, their living standards will improve and they can at least provide three meals a day for their children, pay their schools fees, buy them clothes to wear and pay their medical bills in case any of them fall sick. 

Isatu L. is the leader of this group. Isatu was born in a village called Mababato about 45 years ago. She is married to a teacher and they have six children. Isatu has sold soft drinks, sugar, cigarettes, butter, batteries, kerosene, etc., for more then 20 years now. She will use this loan to buy the previously mentioned items in larger quantities to add to her current stock.

loans.use: Buy soft drinks, sugar, cigarettes, butter, batteries, kerosene, etc., wholesale

loans.name: Help Woman Gobefo Group

texts.en:
Here are members of the Help Women Gobefo group. They are small-scale businesswomen in Makeni city who want a loan of 500,000 Sierra Leonean leones for each to enable them to expand their businesses. This will be their very first loan from SMT/Kiva. With this loan, they will be able to add more goods to their businesses so that they can attract more customers, make better sales, earn more profit and improve their living standards. 

Aminata W. is the leader of this group. Aminata is now age 50. She was born in Makeni and is married with six children. All of her children are now grown-ups except for one, who is in secondary school.  

Aminata sells gara lappers (locally dyed clothes). She has been in this business for 12 years now. She will use this loan to buy working materials like white cotton, inks, caustic soda, powder and so on.

loans.use: Buy working materials like white cotton, inks, caustic soda, powder and so on

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en: Mohamad is a 48 year old married man with 7 children. He used to work as a salesman in a tobacco company. In 2008, he started working on his own selling tobacco. He buys large amounts of stock which he distributes to the shops to earn an income to help satisfy the needs of the family. Today, Mohamad is requesting $1,200 to buy more inventory, so he can increase his sales and therefore his income.

loans.use: To buy more inventory.

loans.name: Peace And Unity Group

texts.en:
In the photo are members of the Peace and Unity group. They are small scale business people based in Makeni city, in northern Sierra Leone. This is the first loan these entrepreneurs are accessing from SMT/Kiva. With this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more profit and consequently improve their standard of living. 

The leader of this group is Cecilia S. Kpukumu. Cecilia is age 45 and she was born in Makeni. She is married with 4 children. Her husband is a professional worker and her children attend school. For 15 years now, Cecillia has sold market food, such as groundnuts/peanuts, maggie (used to give sauce a sweet taste), salt, tomatoes, vegetable oil, palm-oil (the most popular cooking oil), sugar, etc. With this loan, she will expand her business by buying the above mentioned items wholesale to add to her current stock.

loans.use: To buy ground-nuts, maggie, salt, tomatoes, vegetable oil, palm-oil, sugar, etc.

loans.name: Hodalo

texts.en: Hodalo T. sells cereals and yams in the busy Agoé market in Lomé, Togo. She is married to a customs agent, and they have one child. Mrs. T. began this business in 2008 and is asking for her first loan from WAGES to replenish her stock. Specifically, she will purchase one sack of beans, four sacks of corn, and use the remainder to purchase more yams. By helping Mrs. T. sell these staples in Togolese cuisine, her business will continue to grow.

loans.use: To buy beans, corn, and yams

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samuel M. is 25 years old.  He has been in the transportation business in Naivasha town since 2009.  His mode of transportation has been the bicycle famously known as the bodaboda. It is a cheaper mode of transportation than the motorcycle business.

He was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his second loan. He plans to open a retail shop where he will sell fertilizers with the advancement of this loan.

He hopes to grow his transport business in future, buying a pick-up van to be used to transport goods to the market.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer to sell in retail as a secondary business.

loans.name: Pauline

texts.en:
Pauline is 43 years old and married with seven children, between the ages of 7 and 25. Five of the children are still attending school. She is a farmer near Litein in the South Rift Valley of Kenya. She's been farming for about 20 years and employs two people. She earns her income selling pineapples, maize, bananas, milk, and tea. She says that the main challenge she faces to her business are fluctuating prices for farm produce, despite the constant or rising prices of farm inputs. She is hoping that improved breeds of cows will increase her overall milk production and that she'll find better markets for her farm produce.

She successfully repaid her first loan from Juhudi Kilimo and has requested a new loan through Juhudi to purchase and insure an added dairy cow. She says that the extra income from this loan will primarily help her pay for her children's school fees.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more batik and a sewing machine.

loans.name: Zahra

texts.en: Zahra is a 50 year old married woman with 3 children. She has been working in the tailoring occupation for the past 30 years. She opened her tailoring shop in 2007 to help her children in the household because her husband cannot work anymore. She is a very hardworking and enterprising woman; with the loan requested of $1,000, she will buy additional textiles and a mechanical sewing machine that will facilitate her work and augment the production.

loans.use: To buy additional textiles and a mechanical sewing machine.

loans.name: Yawavi

texts.en: Yawaki K. sells beauty products in Lomé, Togo. She is single and does not have children. She began this business in 2004 and is asking for her first loan from WAGES to resupply her stock. Ms. K. will use this loan to purchase a variety of perfumes, shampoos, and hair gels to satisfy her customers’ demands. By helping Ms. K. beautify Togo, you will help her business grow.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of beauty products.

loans.name: Ayman

texts.en: Ayman is a 28 year old married man. He has been working as a home painter since 2003. He learned this occupation from a friend and he works by taking home projects upon request of clients. Working on a freelance basis, he works on house projects in his town and its surroundings. He’s making a good income with his business. With the help of a loan of $1,200, he managed to expand his business by buying tools and scaffolding needed to ameliorate his work quality and attract more clients.

loans.use: To buy tools and scaffolding needed.

loans.name: Karima

texts.en: Karima A. sells beauty products and soaps in the Agoé region of Lomé, Togo. She is married to a taxi driver, and they have one child. Mrs. A. began this business in 2000 and is now asking for her first loan from WAGES. She will use this loan to resupply her stock of soaps and beauty products. This loan will help Mrs. A. support her business and her family.

loans.use: To buy beauty products and soaps.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase grocery items in bulk.

loans.name: Dina

texts.en:
Dina L. is currently in the business of selling beans, tomatoes and onions at the market and is requesting a loan to purchase bags of beans and onions to sell. Dina is 29 years old and is married to a business man. She has 5 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights, and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase bags of beans and onions to sell.

loans.name: Kayed

texts.en: Kayed has owned a butcher shop since 1998, with a previous 20 years of experience in this field. He's married with 2 unemployed children. He is well known in the whole region for the delicious and clean product types he offers to his clients. His target is to continue his children's education until university. Kayed is asking for a loan of $1,000 to buy cattle in order to increase his business productivity.

loans.use: To buy cattle.

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en: Rebecca Y. is married and has three children. She has received a senior high education. Rebecca sells frozen fish at Elmina, which she has been doing for some time now. Her husband is a fisherman. Rebecca uses her income to support her husband in the payment of school fees and other family responsibilities. Rebecca will use the loan to purchase more fish to be frozen as a way of preserving them to resell. With the new profits from her expanded business, Rebecca plans to save to build a house.

loans.use: To purchase more fish to be frozen.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase grocery goods in bulk.

loans.name: Lilian

texts.en:
Lilian R. is currently in the business of selling cooking oil and beans at the market and is requesting a loan to stock more jerrycans of cooking oil to sell. Lilian is 40 years old and is married to a policeman. She has 4 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a hotel.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights, and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more jerrycans of cooking oil to sell.

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan A. is currently in the business of selling beans and tomatoes at the market, and is requesting a loan to buy other items such as rice, posho (cereals) and potatoes to sell. Susan is 29 years old and is married to a policeman. She has 3 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house to rent.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights, and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy other items such as rice, posho (cereals) and potatoes to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase goods in bulk.

loans.name: Julius

texts.en:
Julius is 38 years old, married to Pamella M., and they have three school going children. Julius is a cobbler within Naivasha town, which he has done for the last seven years. He repairs shoes for clients and also makes new ones to sell, mostly on order.

He was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his second loan. He repaid his first loan well and on time and with this current loan he plans to buy leather for making more shoes which he will display and sell later for a profit to his clients.

His future dream is to move to a permanent shop and stop working from the roadside.

loans.use: To buy leather for making new shoes.

loans.name: Kiden

texts.en:
Kiden A. is currently in the business of selling groundnuts paste and charcoal at the market and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell. Kiden is 39 years old and is married to a business man. She has 4 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a charcoal store.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights, and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more bags of charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase soap, cooking oil, kerosene, matches, and salt in bulk

loans.name: Hasan

texts.en: Hasan is a 19-year-old single man living with his parents. He has owned a barber shop in his town since 2007. The young man caters to a wide range of clientele in the village and its surroundings. Like the majority of families, he cooperates with his family to cover the household income. Today, Hasan wishes to improve the decor of his barbershop and buy supplies needed such as hair gel, hair pomade, etc. In order to do so, Hasan is requesting to borrow US$ 1,000.

loans.use: improve the decor of his barbershop and buy supplies needed

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase another sewing machine and material that used when sewing

loans.name: Kenneth

texts.en:
Kenneth Okumu M. is 24 years old and comes from Nyalenda in Kisumu city. He is married to Josephine Okidi and they have one daughter who is six years old. He is currently running a butchery business which is located in a village shopping centre. His clients mainly consist of neighboring hotel owners and local tenders from the schools around.

Kenneth is not new to Kadet though he has managed to service his previous loan well and has a good credit history. He hopes to get a lender to fund his second loan through Kadet Limited which will enable him to purchase some bulls which he intends to rear. This is so that he can avoid purchasing bulls for slaughter and already slaughtered meat to sell. This will increase his meat supply and profit.

His dream is to become the leading supplier of meat in Nyalenda town where his butchery is located. He also hopes to educate his daughter in a high-performing school as well as improve the family’s standard of living.

loans.use: Buying some bulls to rear for slaughter

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en:
Ahmad has owned a car repair shop since 2004 and has ten years of experience in this field. He's a 26-year-old single man living alone. He repairs all type of cars and that’s why he attracts more clients to his shop.

Today, Ahmad is asking to borrow $1,000 to buy new tools needed for his shop and also to buy more spare parts to enlarge his shop to meet the requirements of his clients and to make a good income.

loans.use: To buy new tools for his shop and more spare parts

loans.name: Jacob

texts.en:
Jacob is 34 years old, married to Serah Njeri, and they have four school going children. He has been transporting goods for his clients to the market using a cart pulled by his donkey in Naivasha town for the last five years.

He was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his second loan. He plans to buy another donkey and a cart to help him move more goods to the market, at the same time also improving his income. He will employ someone else to operate the new cart.

In future he plans to open a wholesale shop.

loans.use: To buy another donkey.

loans.name: Bernard

texts.en:
Benard O. K. is twenty-nine years old, married and has three children. He sells books to the college students, pupils and parents of school going children. His business is located off the highway in Oile market in Kisumu, Kenya. He has been doing this business for the last fifteen years and admits there are challenges of competition, bad weather and harrassment by the city council.

However, he is determined to grow his business and open his up his own bookshop in town. He is using his loan to buy more books to sell and he hopes to be the leading seller of reading materials. He is hardworking, patient and honest.

loans.use: To purchase books.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase plates, dishes, jugs,and other products in bulk.

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John is 25 years old and has been operating a transport business in Naivasha town since 2008. His mode of transport is the bicycle, known as boda boda here, which is a cheaper option to the motorcycle.

He was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his second loan from the organisation. He plans to venture into livestock farming as a secondary income generating business, thus he plans to use the money to buy two bulls and ten goats to rear and sell later at a profit.

His future ambition is to grow the livestock business and become a big supplier of both cattle and goat meat meat in Naivasha town.

loans.use: To buy 2 Bulls and 10 goats to start livestock farming.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase vitenge and kanga in bulk.

loans.name: Firas

texts.en: Firas has owned a citrus fruit project since 2006. He opened this type of project after seeing a need for such services in the region and because this kind of business makes a good income for the person. He is the one who supports his wife and only child with this business. Once the harvest is cultivated, he distributes it to the market. Today, Firas is requesting to borrow $1,000 to buy new tools to augment the cultivation.

loans.use: To buy new agricultural tools.

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce A. is currently in the business of selling charcoal, beans and groundnuts, and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of groundnuts to sell.  Joyce is 45 years old and is married to a businessman. She has 6 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a store and educate her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights, and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more bags of  groundnuts to sell.

loans.name: Orakwue

texts.en: Orakwue is a happy mother with 4 lovely children. She is married to a businessman and he also supports the home. Orakwue is a good cook and she cooks both Nigerian and western foods very well. Her customers come from all parts of the city to purchase her cooked foods and drinks. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She hopes for a loan amount of NGN 80,000 to purchase more drinks and foodstuffs to cook and sell. She is happy because her profits will increase with the Kiva loan. She has a good relationship with LAPO. She truly thanks all Kiva lenders for their unflinching support.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and foodstuffs to cook and sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase goods in bulk that will be used at grocery.

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan I. is currently in the business of selling beans at the market and is requesting a loan to purchase more bags of beans to sell. Susan is 26 years old and is married to a driver. She has 2 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a beauty salon.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights, and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of beans to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase goods in bulk

loans.name: Amira

texts.en: Amira is a 48-year-old married woman and mother of 3 children. She has been working as a farmer for the past 14 years. The region she lives in is specific to this agricultural sector, that's why she learned this occupation when she has still very young. She cultivates all kind of vegetables and distributes the harvest to the vegetable shops she works with. Today, Amira is requesting to borrow US$ 1,000 to buy farming tools and seedlings to increase her business productivity and thus her income.

loans.use: buy farming tools and seedlings

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase rice in bulk

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase shoes in bulk

loans.name: Adlene

texts.en: Adlene is a 31-year-old married woman. After having her first child, the household become overloaded with a lot of expenses. So Adlene decided to work as a home-based tailor. She has been involved in this business since 2005. And she’s thankful to her small business because she’s able to help her husband support the family. Today, Adlene is requesting to borrow US$ 1,000 to purchase 2 sewing machines to offer a variety of products and to satisfy the heavy demand of her customers.

loans.use: purchase 2 sewing machines

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth N. Makokha is 38 years old, married with three children, living in Kwirare Busia District. She used to be a farmer planting subsistence crops that were not generating enough income. In 1993, Elizabeth went into the fish business with the aim of generating enough income to sustain her family.

Being in this business for more than fifteen years and having learnt about KMET's loan system that works only with determined groups, Elizabeth has seen the need for expanding her business by increasing her stock to ensure enough income for economic sustainability.

She would like to get a loan worth Ksh.20,000 to achieve this and also her future plans for economic development.

loans.use: to increase her stock and expand the business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase cooking oil, rice, kerosene, and flour in bulk

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase goods in bulk

loans.name: Consolata

texts.en:
Consolata T. Ekasiba is a 48-year-old married mother of seven children who lives in Igara Busia District and sells cereals in the nearby Miyanga market, a business she started in 2005 as a source for generating income.

With her future goal being educating her children, Consolata would like to increase her stock to be able to generate enough income to achieve this. It is for this reason she would like to get a loan worth Ksh. 10,000 that will be (to some extent) influential to her business putting her somewhat ahead as far as fulfilling her goal is concerned.

loans.use: increase cereals stock

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Alphonce

texts.en:
Alphonce is 47 years old, married to Priscah O., and they have three school-going children. He has been selling spray paint for motor vehicles in Naivasha town since 2004.

He was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his second loan. He plans to buy more paint to sell to re-stock his business.

His future plans are not just to supply the paint retail but also wholesale.

loans.use: Buy more paints for sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase beans, rice, cooking oil, kerosene, & soap in bulk

loans.name: Loice

texts.en:
Loice C. is a 37-year-old married mother of two children who live in Kwirare Busia District. 
She used to do subsistence farming but changed to fish vending in 2006 to boost her income.
With a plan of better education for her children, Loice wants to expand her business by increasing her stock to ensure economic stability for her family. It is for this reason she wants a loan of Ksh.10,000 to be able to achieve this.

loans.use: To increase her stock

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Laura

texts.en: Laura works as a beautician and has 16 years of experience in this occupation. She's married with four children. Two of her children are still unemployed. She works from her home where she receives clients in addition to working on a traveling basis.  She is well known in this occupation due to the long time she has been in the field and to her experience and good quality of work. Today, Laura is requesting to borrow $1,000 to purchase beauty tools and supplies to reinforce her work and increase her profit.

loans.use: To purchase beauty tools and supplies

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase beans, maize, and rice in bulk

loans.name: Patricia

texts.en:
Patricia Etiang’ is a farmer who plants and sells vegetables, a business she started in 2002 after quitting poultry farming. She buys her seedlings twice a year from the nearest market.

She is 42 years old, married and the mother of eight (8) children. She lives in Igara in the Busia District. 
Patricia started her business to generate income with a plan of expanding it to generate enough income to be able to educate her children for a better future. In this regard, Patricia would like to get a loan worth Ksh.10,000 to be able to achieve all these goals.

loans.use: To buy seeds and prepare her farm

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en: Josephine sells generators at retail prices to her customers in Lagos state, Nigeria. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She hopes for a loan of NGN 120,000 to purchase more generators to sell. She has seven years of experience in her business. She is 38 years old and single with a child. Her child is seven years old and in school. She hopes to grow her business with the loan. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more generators to sell

loans.name: Pauliine

texts.en:
Pauline O. is a poultry farmer who started her business in 2009 after quitting her job as an Early Childhood Development (ECD) tutor due to poor income. To generate income, Pauline buys her stock every two months and wants to expand her business to be able to secure, for her children, a better education for a bright future.

At the age of 32 years, Pauline is a married woman and a mother of two (2) children living in Kwirare Busia District.  She would like a loan worth Ksh.10,000 to be able to increase her stock to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase more poultry and feed

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Abdul S.'s Group

texts.en:
These are teachers at one of the secondary schools in Makeni city. This school was established on the 4th of September 1980 to promote Islamic education in Makeni city and it environs. The school currently has 55 teachers and 2,060 pupils in the Junior Secondary school and 1,200 pupils in the Senior Secondary school. 

School staff from this institution, like many other schools staff within SMT’s operational areas, comes to SMT to apply for loans. With the help of these loans, they can accomplish certain tasks that they would otherwise not be able to accomplish with their mere salaries alone. But with the help of this loan, some can pay school fees for their children; others can use the loan to buy pieces of furniture, a plot of land, house-building materials, or invest in a business. At the end of each month, these teachers can repay the loan out of their monthly salaries. The institution’s bursar is directly responsible for deducting the repayment and pays SMT on their behalf.

50-year-old Abdul S. B. (last row, second from left) is the principal at the school.  He was born in Makeni. He is married with eight children. Abdul will use this loan to pay school fees for his children and invest the rest in his business.

loans.use: Pay school fees for his children

loans.name: Pamela

texts.en:
Pamela K. is 38 years old, married and the mother of eight (8) children. She lives in the Igara Busia District where she does her food business. She started her business in 2008 to generate income to help her husband bring up their children. Before she started her current business, Pamela used to sell groceries but had to change, as it was not generating enough income.  Now she restocks her products on a daily basis.

As a mother, Pamela has a big dream for her children. She wants all of them to get an education that would guarantee them a bright future. Having learned from KMET about economic empowerment, Pamela developed an urge to expand her business by buying more supplies and to start a poultry farm that would boost her income. To achieve all this, she needs a loan worth Ksh.10,000.

loans.use: To buy more stock and chicks

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Nkeachi

texts.en: Nkeachi specializes in the sales of electronics and cooking utensils. This is the business she's been in for a remarkable four years. However, she is itching for a significant expansion of her business. With a loan of NGN 100,000, she will purchase more electronics and cooking utensils to sell. She is married to a plumber and they have four lovely children. Her children are excelling in their schoolwork. Her youngest child is standing besides her in the picture. She has a good relationship with LAPO. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more electronics and cooking utensils to sell

loans.name: Mildred

texts.en:
Mildred Nasamu Masika, a 39-year-old married mother of five children living in Kwirare Busia District, has been making and selling clothes at the nearby Miyanga market since 2002. Before starting this business she was a clerk but had to quit due to low income. She travels as far as Bungoma and Malaba every two months, depending upon demand, to purchase her stock.

Mildred wants to achieve the self-reliance that will only come through economic stability, and to achieve this, she wishes to expand her business by increasing her stock and is therefore requesting a loan worth Ksh.20000.

loans.use: To increase her material stock

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en:
Catherine N. Wakhis, a businesswoman who sells cereals in Miyanga market and lives in Kwirare Busia District, is 40 years old, married and a mother of six children. In her business, Catherine buys her stock twice a week within the same market she sells her goods. With a loan worth Ksh.15000, she wishes to expand her business by increasing her stock.

Her future plan is to venture into selling fish wholesale, an enterprise that will enable her to generate enough income to be able to educate her children and sustain her entire family.

loans.use: To increase her business stock

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes N. Nyongesa is a 51 year old married mother with five (5) children. She lives and operates her fish business in Kwirare Busia District.
In 2005 she started her business, after quitting farming that she had been doing since getting married but was generating little income. She buys her stock in Port Victoria on a monthly basis and sells them in Mayanga market.

With future plans of a better education for her children, Agnes would wish to acquire a loan worth Ksh.20000 that will enable her open a retail shop and generate more income for her plans to be achieved.

loans.use: To open a retail shop in a bid to expand her business.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine N. is a hardworking business lady selling cereals in Miyanga market while she lives in the nearby village called Igara in Busia District. She is aged 38 years, is married, and is the mother of five children.

Josephine used to do farming but abandoned it to start her new business early in 2009 for income generation. She buys her stock twice a week and has a determination to expand her business by engaging in building rental houses. She believes this will put her in a stable economic position that will guarantee her children a better education for a brighter future.

To achieve this, Josephine would like to acquire a loan of Ksh 20,000.

loans.use: To buy more cereals and also build a rental house

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice O. grows maize which she sells in Igara Busia District where she also lives with her seven children. She is 40 years old, is married, and started her business in 2007 after quitting selling liquor because the business was marred by police interference almost on a daily basis.

Beatrice buys her stock every two weeks and wishes to upgrade her farming with a loan of Ksh 25,000. Her future plan is to be economically stable that will make her be self reliant keeping poverty at bay.

loans.use: To upgrade her farm

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Electina

texts.en:
Electina N. is a businesswoman who lives in Kwirare, Busia District. She is aged 30 years, is married, and is the mother of three children.

Electina’s tailoring business dates back to 2005 after she quit her subsistence farming that was not generating any income for the family.

Electina travels as far as Malaba for her stock on a monthly basis but this is not yet enough as she wants to expand her business by increasing her stock. That will put her in a better position to educate her children. She wishes to obtain a loan of Ksh 20,000 to be able to achieve this.

loans.use: To increase her stock and expand her business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Alex Manuel

texts.es:
Alex tiene 25 años de edad, es conviviente hace 3 años, tiene una hija de 2 años de 
edad. El vive en casa de sus padres con su familiar. El inicio en el negocio 
aproximadamente hace 3 años, en donde adquirió la mototaxi con las utilidades 
obtenidas en la temporada que se dedico a la minería informal. El tiene brindando este 
servicio ya hace 3 años. Alex y su cónyuge sueñan con tener su casa propia ya que por 
el momento los están ayudando sus padres. Alex destina todos los ingresos que obtiene 
a la manutención de su menor hija. Alex solicita el crédito para realizar el mantenimiento de su mototaxi y para la  compra de algunos repuestos, para asi no tener problemas con su herramienta de trabajo.
texts.en:
Alex is 25 years old, and has lived with a partner for 3 years. He has a 2 year-old daughter. He lives with his family in his parent's house. He started up his business about 3 years ago, when he acquired a mototaxi (light, 3-wheeled passenger vehicle) with the earnings he made during the time he worked in the informal mining sector. He has provided mototaxi service for 3 years. Alex and his partner dream of having their own home, since at the moment they are being helped by his parents. Alex uses all of his earnings for the support of his young daughter. Alex requests a loan to use to perform maintenance work on his mototaxi, and to buy some spare parts for it, so that he will not have problems with his instrument of work.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to maintain his mototaxi

loans.name: Khudaverdi

texts.en: Khudaverdi M. is a 46-year-old man who runs his own shop. He sells different kinds of home products. He is married and has three children. Khudaverdi has nine years of experience in his business. Now he needs 1,600 Azerbaijan New Manat to purchase more products to sell.

loans.use: Purchase more products to increase income

loans.name: Orlando

texts.es:
El señor Orlando vive en anticretico juntamente con su familia, en la zona de Alto san Pedro, de la ciudad de La Paz. 
El señor Orlando Trabaja como operador de amplificación en la zona de Sopocachi de la Ciudad de la Paz, los ingresos que recibe es para mantener a su mama el cual es mayor de edad.
El crédito solicitado es para la ampliación del anticretico que tiene y así poder acceder a una habitación más y tener mayor comodidad.
Esta es la tercera vez que solicita préstamo y el análisis socioeconómico realizado lo califica favorablemente y puede acceder  a un  crédito.
texts.en:
Mr. Orlando lives in an anticretico with his family, in the Alto San Pedro zone of the city of La Paz. An anticretico is a unique, legal method of housing in which the owner of the building allows a person to live for a determined amount of time in exchange for a set amount of money, which will be returned at the end of the living period. Mr Orlando works as a amplification operator in the Sopocachi zone in La Paz. His income supports his elderly mother. The loan that he is requesting if for the enlargement of the anticretico to add another room and make it more confortable. This is the third time that he requests a loan. The socioeconomic analysis qualifies him for this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Bobbit, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Cost of adding an additional room to the house where he and his mother live.
